dialogues.text: Mucking about - running around with the dog. One of thing they lie down together, lighting matches with a lighter. Note: We can also do this in school. Running along the beach with burning sticks like this http://www. youtube.com/watch?v=XVnRzEjpUmE Lying by a bonfire at the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER and Jordana run around with sticks smashing up derelict areas THEY place something in a bin - they run away - the bin explodes Burning OLIVER’S leg hair in a den Throwing FRENCH banger fireworks They throw BLUE, RED and WHITE PAINT over an old bath. A SMALL fire display (as per the test) by the beach. CLOSE SHOT FIRE REFLECTED IN JORDANA’S EYES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 32A. JORDANA rollerskates past bins with the LIGHT ENTERTAINME fire effect in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 33. We cut to various STOCK FOOTAGE of FIRE. A

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jordana loves fire. We have a close up of JORDANA, 50 fps, we overlay the boa and our stock footage over it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everything about her makes me think of fire. Our relationship is a gleaming rocket blasting me into the school’s social stratosphere. Fireworks burn behind her until flames engulf the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA and OLIVER are now sitting next to one another. S is flaming the underside of her desk. She shows OLIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of kids are hanging out. CHIPS, OLIVER, KEIRON an a couple of others.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: How long’s it been? Two weeks? It's fucking ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m not bothered. We’ve as good as done it. Everything but.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: It should never take more than a week between everything but and stuffing it in. She’s taking the piss. Keiron - back me up.

dialogues.speaker: KEIRON
dialogues.text: She's taking the piss, mate.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Turn round - she’s seen us. Is she still looking?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes.  51 52 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 33A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA and OLIVER are mooching along after school. OLIVE looks pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER and JORDANA sit on a bench, overlooking the water.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 34.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This is nice, isn’t it? JORDANA looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I mean, we get on pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s not bad.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We're getting more and more intimate.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: (mocking) Intimate? She has started to blacken the end of a rubber with a CLIPPER lighter. PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes. We’ve done things. We've been intimate.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: We have been intimate, yes. My parents normally go out on Thursdays. To the cinema. It’s a tradition they have. They go every Thursday evening. So, what I’m saying is it’s empty - the house; on Thursday the house is empty. It’s an empty house. So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you asking me to come round and have sex with you?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: If I say yes, does that lessen the chances of you wanting to?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Before I answer that, I just want to check one thing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sure. Anything.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 34A.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: It’s quite serious.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Of course. Feel free.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Will the house be empty?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s very funny.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Write down the reasons why I should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 35. WE CUT to: Oliver scribbling in his notebook. He shows it to JORDANA. INSERT, HER POV of the list: A 1. You’re fatally in love with me. 2. Best to do it before it’s legal. 3. Bound to be disappointing, so why wait? Jordana takes OLIVER'S pen and puts a line through ‘you'r fatally in love with me’.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s go burn something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER and JORDANA watch fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER wanders downstairs. He’s wearing a JACKET that’s much too big. To his horror, his parents are still there. LLOYD is fiddling with the fish tank.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Going out?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s Thursday. You're going to the cinema, right? You should go immediately.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Is that what you wear to lounge around the house?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Your father doesn’t want to go out all of a sudden-

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Jill - you know I’ve been looking forward to it. I just didn’t realise we were going to be joined by ‘others’. Is that my jacket?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Please. They’re our neighbours. It’s only right to be welcoming.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Who. The ninjas? Can I wear it?  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 35A.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It's Thursday night. It’s our cinema night. Not a free for all.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Don’t call them ninjas. It’s racist.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He’s white.  54 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 36.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: They don’t strike me as admirers of Eric Rohmer. (to Jill) Maybe you three go and see some tat at the Odeon. I’1l stay in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You should both definitely go. THE DOORBELL SOUNDS. Everyone FREEZES. LLOYD and OLIVER hide so that they can’t be seen from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Hi Jill. You look great.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh thanks...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I know this is a bit early, but there’s a great little noodle place near the cinema and we'd love you to join us- our treat.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Why don’t we head down together - save taking two cars. There's plenty of room in the VW.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: That’s very sweet of you. (shouts )

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: OFF LLOYD and OLIVER’S REACTIONS we CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM'S VAN is parked outside. Kim-Lin is sat in the front. GRAHAM leads JILL to the other front seat.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I love your hair like that, by the way. You look amazing, doesn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: KIM-LIN
dialogues.text: You look amazing, Jill 54  55

dialogues.speaker: 55A
dialogues.text: 56 57 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 37.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (to LLOYD) You alright in the back, mate?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Lovely. The back of the van is filed with crates of videos of ‘Th Graham T. Purvis System’ as well as massage oils and posters. LLOYD picks up a bottle that’s rolling around in the back. It says ‘SENSUAL MASSAGE OIL’. The bottles sticky - he tries to wipe his hands on the wall. OLIVER WATCHES, invisible behind the net curtains.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OLIVER'S HOUSE- EVENING
dialogues.text: He runs in and out of his parents bedroom with various items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER sits in a chair and waits. And waits. Finally he hears the doorbell. He gets up and hares to the door. JORDANA is there. She has roller skates on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. OLIVER’S HOUSE. KITCHEN/DINING ROOM- EVENING OLIVER has prepared quite an elaborate meal and has set the table with candles/flowers. JORDANA sits down. He pulls out her chair. She has white socks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: How was the toilet?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Fine...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m starving. You’ve very late - it doesn’t matter etc He pours them each some wine. From a BOX OF WINE. OLIVER raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gambled on white. To us, anda wonderful evening of lovemaking. JORDANA doesn’t know where to look. 55

dialogues.speaker: 55A
dialogues.text: 56 57  58 59 60 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 38. INT. OLIVER'S HOUSE. HIS PARENT’S BEDROOM- EVENING He shows JORDANA into the bedroom. He has changed the bul to red. Soft music is playing. There are red balloons. There’s an ice bucket with wine in and condoms laid out o the pillows.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Fucking hell, you're a serial 58 killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER is waiting while JORDANA ties her roller skates back on.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You may as well have this, then. It is an envelope with ‘JORDANA, WITH THANKS’ written on it. She leaves. OLIVER sinks back against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA is roller skates along. She takes the envelope ou of her pocket. She tears it open and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Jordana, thank you for letting me explore your perfect body. I could drink your blood. You’re the only person I would allow to be shrunk down to microscopic size and swim inside me in a tiny submersible machine. We've lost our virginity. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61 62 63 64 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 39.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But it wasn’t like losing anything. You’re too good for me. You’re too good for anyone. Sincerely, Oliver. A SMILE creeps onto JORDANA’S FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER opens the door. He sees JORDANA.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: You're not really right, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER lies on his back while JORDANA puts on her clothes He is beaming. She seems to be looking for something. We see OLIVER'S POV of JORDANA’S PANTS. He pushes them under the bed with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA roller skates next to Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANNA
dialogues.text: Will you try and find my pants?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. They’1ll be there somewhere. They won’t have disappeared. He walks her down the road. They don’t speak for a bit

dialogues.speaker: JORDANNA
dialogues.text: Don’t get cocky. She skates away. OLIVER walks into the middle of the road and looks after her. We CUT between their POVs of eachother as they get further away.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. OLIVER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: LLOYD and JILL walk in, their faces stormy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: How was the film?  65 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 40.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I think it’s nice to see something lightweight once in a while. Something where you don’t have to think.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Relationships are tough, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You should be in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is reading the ENCYCLOPEDIA

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tonight I stumbled across an encyclopedia entry on ultrasound. Ultrasound is a sound vibration too high-frequency to be audible. We see accompanying stock footage throughout the followin - in the style of a NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC documentary. SOUN WAVES; MARITIME FOOTAGE, MAPS, SCIENTISTS etc

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was first developed in the Second World War to locate submerged objects: depth charges, submarines, Atlantis and such. It is used by doctors to study hard- to-reach body areas. We see examples of this.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: During pregnancy you can detect a foetus’ heart beat using an ultrasonic stethoscope. We see and hear an ultrasonic display of an unborn baby B before cutting to illustrative archive of the following.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some animals, like bats, dolphins and dogs can hear within the ultrasonic frequency but no human can. No one can see inside someone else. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 41.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No one can truly know what anyone else thinks or feels. What’s inside mum? What’s inside dad? What's inside Jordana? WE cut to still images of JORDANA, JILL and LLOYD. THEY turn into EAGLE annual style cut outs. Where we see their component parts illustrated.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're all travelling under the radar, undetected, and no one can do a thing about it. INT CINEMA — DAY OLIVER hands JORDANA some books from his bag.. KING LEAR, NEITZCHE and CATCHER IN THE RYE.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I got you these books. Because they’re all really meaningful to me. This is probably Shakespeare’s most mature work. It’s miles better than Hamlet. It’s just more developed. Thematically.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This is Neitzche - he’s probably the most influential philosopher of modern times. I don’t agree with everything he says, but he makes some interesting points.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: And this is The Catcher in the Rye. A great example of the modern American novel. Salinger’s very influential.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I thought it could be nice to develop some mutual interests now that we’ve had sex. You know - other than spitting and setting things on fire. 66  67 68 69 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 42.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Why would I want to be more like you?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Try not to crack the spines. Or burn them. We should go in.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Just one second. She spits on the floor. We push into a poster for CARL THEODOR DREYER’S JOAN OF A outside with the sticker, ‘NOW PLAYING’. Match cut start next scene. Note: We need someone to work in the foyer an possibly an usher.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's very rude to leave a film before it’s finished.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Who to?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: The filmmakers.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: How are they going to know?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: They just do. OLIVER sees his mother with GRAHAM on the road outside th cinema. JILL has just come out of the hairdressers and ha a slightly different do. Graham is admiring it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kiss me. He brings JORDANA close to him and kisses her. He uses he as a human shield as he spins her around, keeping his MOTHER and GRAHAM in his view. Jill and Graham walk to hi van and drive off.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 42A.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: What... The fuck... Was that? ‘Kiss me!'?? Did you seriously just say kiss me? Did I dream that? etc

dialogues.speaker: 74A
dialogues.text: 75 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER walks alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER enters. The door closes with a thud behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER walks past his PARENTS’ BEDROOM. His father, LLOYD is sitting in bed, fully clothed, staring into the middle distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER is looking through JILL'S box of mementoes, he finds two pictures of his mum. The drawing and the sunlit one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER hears his mum come back in the through the front d He listens as she goes into to see LLOYD. But he can’t he anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER eats a lonely meal.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Is it possible that my mum would cheat on Dad? Would they get divorced? They don’t even row. They just have discussions. I can imagine my mother calmly leaving one day while my Dad helps her to pack. We cut to this scene, LLOYD chirpily polite, JILL self- A absorbed and unemotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 44. INT. OLIVER’S HOUSE. HALL - LATER- EVENING 76 OLIVER sees a leaflet advertising the Graham T. Purvis System. ‘ It has Graham’s face on it and a load of jargon about ‘self-actualising’; ‘complete psychic and physical rejuvinatinon’; ‘Holistic equipment for excellence’. OLIVER turns it over. There is an official phone number. We see in pen: ‘Call for your free session!’. He picks up the phone to dial. We hear the voice of JACKIE (ZOE’s MOTHER). OLIVER covers his mouth so that his breathing won’t be audible.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Nothing. There’s nothing going on.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Come on —

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. Just the usual blah.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s the usual blah?

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just Oliver being Oliver. Lloyd being Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is Lloyd still taking the - JiLL How do you know that. Did I tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes - do they work -

dialogues.speaker: JI1L, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sort of - but he refuses to take them. He says he’d rather be sad than numb whatever that means. He doesn’t think about giving me a break. I’d love to feel numb. OLIVER writes: ‘Dad - still medicated?’  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 44A.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Any more word from Graham?  77 78

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 45.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing to report really. We all went to the cinema. Normal.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And how was that?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Awkward of course. Lloyd sulked because we watched Crocodile Dundee rather than one of his specials. One of his dark. But I really laughed. I thought it was very charming. And I can see why someone like her would go for someone like him.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Well, Graham’s still very attractive - he probably felt threatened -—

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Lloyd is far too self-involved to feel threatened.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He knows Graham was your first love and it probably -

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: He wasn’t my first love.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh come on.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I was eighteen

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Pardon.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Eighteen!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I was in love at 18. 77 78  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 45A.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: No I wasn’t. You were in love with the idea of being in love.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I was, with Colin. Do you remember Colin?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Not really. I’ve got to go  79 80 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 46.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve just remembered something. I’1ll call you back. I‘1l see you tomorrow. We hear the dial tone. OLIVER quickly cradles the phone and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lloyd! Were you listening in to that?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What? JILL (0.S.). I can hear you breathe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER looks out of his window at GRAHAM’S HOUSE, GRAHAM is doing aggressive Karate type moves on his own.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This doesn’t look good. OLIVER reaches into his pocket and takes out a small pouc made from kitchen roll. In it are some of Lloyd’s anti- depressants. He takes one, as if to swallow it, then puts it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TATES are eating breakfast in silence. LLOYD is in hi dressing gown, sipping from a mug of hot lemon. Oliver reads a book. LLOYD reads a journal related to his work.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Are you planning on getting dressed today?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Do you want to take the car?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I can take the bus. JILL gets up and scrapes the remainder of her cornflakes the sink.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I think I’1l work from home today. Take the car.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 47.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I’m thinking of going to one Graham's talks tonight

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You don’t mind?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Why would I mind?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Fine. Well it means I won’t be in tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’1ll make sure I’m busy.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (to OLIVER) Oliver? Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I'd just like to have a moment with my father if that’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Lovely. I’1l see you in the car. He watches her leave. He turns the tap on to hide his voice. He then whispers to LLOYD

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I think mum might be having an affair.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Can you turn the tap off please?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I saw her in town with Graham. And I heard her on the phone talking about him.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t spy on people, Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I wasn’t spying. I just saw them. And I picked up the phone by accident. Aren’t you worried?  81 82 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 WE see JILL hovering by the door. We see her POV of OLIVER and LLOYD TALKING A

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Graham is an old friend of your mum's.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Did you know they’ve been meeting up?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: So you're condoning this affair?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: There is no affair, Oliver. He’s just some bloke I stole your mother from.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: So you admit they have a history?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You should go with your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER tries to do the gears. JILL swats his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Thanks mum.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oliver, just a second. We’re early. OLIVER looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How are things with Jordana?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Are you ever going to let us meet her?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Maybe if you get a terminal illness RED 48.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 49.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Are things serious between you two? OLIVER shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because it may seem like a big deal now, but there are other things in life. It probably won't matter much when you’re my age.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: When I’m thirty-eight?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Just be careful.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I always use condoms. JILL doesn’t know how to take this.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You know that me and your dad are going through a rough patch-

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yah.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: and I want to know that I really appreciate your trying to help...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You're a loud whisperer, Ol

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t spy on people.  83

dialogues.speaker: 83X
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 50.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why have you been meeting up with Graham?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Graham’s an old friend. He’s going through a tough time. He’s been having some relationship problems with Kim-Lin and he needed someone he could talk to.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: So he might be single soon?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: So goodbye, Ol. OLIVER gets out of the car. He leans in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Mum: Who would you save first in a house fire given the hypothetical situation that both dad and I were equally difficult to save?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I’d go for you. But I’d feel bad for your father. She drives off. OLIVER, turns and sees JORDANA. A

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Kiss me! etc (she prattles on a little) He reluctantly walks towards her.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Colour is energy. Energy equals emotion. Emotion is life. Colour is life. We say red with anger. Black with despair. Green with envy. We use this words in life. What do these colours mean to you? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 ptl 84 pt2 84 pt3 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 51.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How can recognising the energies of colours help us live a more balanced life? INT. LEISURE CENTRE LOBBY - NIGHT 84 ptl We see POSTERS with GRAHAM’S FACE on them. A group of abo forty people are gathered in a room in the leisure centre OLIVER PEERS through a crack in the door. He looks at 84 a point of sale filled with Graham's videos. GRAHAM has a flip chart outlining the principles of his theory. During this speech he takes us through it. We jum cut as he talks through the night, to give snippets of hi ramblings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham talks. WE have some audience participation. Graham describes how he came up with his theory Graham talks about how he was depressed after Heatseekers describes what Heatseekers was He talks about how the gift is a burden, and how people thought he was mad - how he went to every eye doctor in t country. But he does see colours. You will not see colours, but the principles may help you lives - that’s all. I’m not a magic man. I’m not a shaman It’s about balance. Reduce the red in you, and bring the colours into balance. Exercise and eating right are part of this. INT. LEISURE CENTRE LOBBY - NIGHT 84 pt3 OLIVER reacts.

dialogues.speaker: 84B
dialogues.text: 85 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 52. INT. LEISURE CENTRE - NIGHT 84a The talk ends, APPLAUSE. PEOPLE GET UP, spill out of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER hides by the stairs and looks for his mother. His mother doesn’t appear. He returns to the door and looks i He sees his mother talking to Graham.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming. It means a lot.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: No. It was interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’1l just wait in the car. JACKIE exits via the fire escape. GRAHAM and JILL talk.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I make a comment?  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 53.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I suppose it depends what it is.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I like your friend. I think she patronises you.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I think she treats you like a child. Like that comment about how she'd wait for you in the car. It belittles you. etc

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: What did you think of the show?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Yes - interesting etc

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You think i’m silly

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You do

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Honestly, I don’t etc

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: All I can say is that it works for me. I’m happy.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: And now you’re going to ask me if I’m happy...?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I am yes etc

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That gladdens me. I broke up with Kim Lin

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Sorry  Laughter. SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 53A.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: She was young. I need a woman.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I’m going to get back.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I remember you being happy.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Honestly. LLoyd will be wondering where I am.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: How is Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: He’s well.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Are you going to come again?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Promise? Don’t make me cross the street and drag you down! You should bring Lloyd down.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure he’d like it. But thanks.

dialogues.speaker: 85D
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 54-55.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m sure he’d come if you asked.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Are you alright there

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yeah - just going to take a few beats. JILL walks away, via the fire escape, and looks over her shoulder. GRAHAM stares after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER REACTS, then decides to walk in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You don’t fool me. I know what you're up to.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: What am I up to?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: We’re done here. I’ve said what I need to. I’m watching you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: What am I up to? OLIVER walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER walks, looking at a copy of Graham’s video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER watches a tape of Graham’s video.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mum is the exact type of person who's susceptible to this mystic bullshit. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + Oe  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 56.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can picture her telling Jackie at work how it it’s a bit of over the top but there’s ‘something in it’. First she’ll just start meeting Graham more often. Then he’1l start giving her deep tissue massages. Then he’1l make her join him in some mystic commune with a bunch of other still-fairly-attractive mothers and cut them off from their families and the world while he passes around his sperm and says it’s magic milk. How’s my dad meant to compete? If he radiated a colour, it'd be ochre.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He knows the number for the pothole help-line off by heart. SHOT OF LLOYD BY A PAYPHONE looking a pothole in the road

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was the first person in our village to install double glazing. F We see LLOYD by his double glazed window. F  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 57.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The only time I saw him enthrall a room was when he gave a talk about the disappearance of a giant sturgeon from the museum of Cardiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a brief excerpt of this speech. A man has just asked a question.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You're right. Sturgeons are royal fish, since the 14th century anyway, and if caught, they do become the property of the crown. So yes, the matter is being treated as suspicious. A small boy sitting next to OLIVER puts up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SMALL BOY
dialogues.text: How deep is the ocean?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: At it’s deepest point, 7 miles, but on average, 6 miles is a good rule of thumb. But no fish could live down there, there’s, of course no light and the pressure’s to great. Any human who was at that level would die immediately. They’d implode. They wouldn’t have a chance. But yes, six miles deep.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s time for dad to tear off his vest again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LLOYD, JILL and OLIVER at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s a bit over the top, but there’s something in it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Right, yes. Good turn out, was it? OLIVER’S heart sinks.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 58.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m going to go out for a bit. 89 EXT. STREET OUTSIDE OLIVER’S HOUSE - EVENING 89 OLIVER approaches GRAHAM’S van. He tries, and eventually succeeds in making himself sick on the bonnet.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I decided to meet Jordana. I felt like setting fire to something. But tonight, for the first time, she used a word I’d never heard before -

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: It’s called a medulloblastoma.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: It means she’s got a brain tumour. A long pause. JORDANA’S dog starts to whimper

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -or told me that her mum has cancer. And in the top trumps of parental problems, cancer beats infidelity. How will I reconcile this with rule 3 of our charter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER trudges home. He reaches home. By now it’s raining He looks over at GRAHAM’S VAN. The vomit has been washed away. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: A CAPTION
dialogues.text: B SCHOOL ESTABLISHERS to show it’s nearly CHRISTMAS. NOTE OLIVER should be playing the piano in the hall. Some kids (6-10) come in dressed in Nativity wear (wise men/angels) led by a teacher.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 59.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Things are a lot less fun since Jordana’s mother might die and my parents’ marriage started falling apart. I’ve been working on strategies to solve both problems. I’ve bought my Dad some new aftershave, but I’m drawing a blank on the cancer situation. I’ve ordered some books on how to relate to people in crisis to read over the holidays. Oliver is staring at JORDANA’S EMPTY DESK. THE BELL SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: MR DAVEY
dialogues.text: Okay - walk! You’re still in school! And if anyone hasn't signed the card to Jordana Bevan, now’s the last chance. Have a good Christmas everyone.

dialogues.speaker: PUPILS
dialogues.text: Thanks Mr. Davey etc

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: You're fucked, mate. Even if her mum is terminal it can still take fucking ages.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Please, Chips -

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: This is not what you signed up for. This was about dipping your wick. You’ve done that. Game over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pupils are rushing to get out. It’s the last class of the Christmas term.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: And I’m telling you - she is going to be in no mood to put out anymore. No yuletide logging for you. Unlike me, who'll be rolling in it throughout the festive season  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 59A.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: God you’re lame. Do you actually think of these lines in advance?  94

dialogues.speaker: 94A
dialogues.text: 95 96 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 60.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: I just spit lines as they come to me, mate.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: You've got to shut this shit down.

dialogues.speaker: KEIRON
dialogues.text: With extreme prejudice.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: Thank you Keiron.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Nothing’s changed.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: Do what you want, mate, but remember two things, Ol. One: treat ‘em mean, keep ‘em keen. And two: don’t mix family and bush. Come on Keiron, let's get the fuck out of here. We see OLIVER, lonely, as the rest of the pupils run off excitedly for the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER and JORDANA are walking along, mournful, with her dog. He tries to put his arm around her, but she shrugs i off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER sits with his arm round JORDANA. She is crying. OLIVER is patting her back in a distant way, unsure what to do he almost looks bored. He exchanges a look with JORDANA’S DOG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s reading a book, Parenting Teens with Love and Logic.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve been taking my duty as a boyfriend seriously. Last night I re-read the book Parenting Teens with Love and Logic. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 60A.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I remembered a chapter that says pets are important because they die because they allow children to adjust to death and mourning. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 98 99 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 61.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s therefore in Jordana’s interest that her dog dies before her mother does. Then we can get things back on track. We see an insert - JORDANA’S DOG - A NECESSARY SACRIFICE? A SHOT OF OLIVER finding the rat poison in a draw in the kitchen. The phone rings. He goes over to open it, rat poison in hand. NOTE: WE NEED TO COVER A VERSION WHERE HE ANSWERS THE PHONE W/OUT RAT POISON IN HAND.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Calm down. What is it? Where are you? He puts the poison back in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER sprints into shot with a shovel and a bin liner. H crosses into the road, out of shot. He re-enters with a f bag and a grim expression. He sits down. OLIVER and JORDANA sit side by side, the shovel next to them, the bin liner on the floor. The bin liner has blood and bits of fur on it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It’s such bad luck. There’s like one train every week here. He was always running off, I guess. I’m sorry. He gives her a hug, and then tries to kiss her.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 62.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: ol - OLIVER falls back on his soap opera cliches.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No- sorry. Of course etc.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: We should bury him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No. We shouldn’t do that. Foxes dig up dead animals and eat them.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: We can’t just leave him in a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA and OLIVER launch a burning boat into the canal. see the sports bag start to burn.
