dialogues.text: Jude would like to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Who's Jude?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: My mum.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 63.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Since when have you called her Jude?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Since she might die in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Would you like to come?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: More than anything. JORDANA gives OLIVER a long hug.

dialogues.speaker: 101A OMITTED 101A
dialogues.text: 102 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 64. INT. JORDANA’S HOUSE - EVENING 102 OLIVER LOOKS AT VARIOUS ORNAMENTS AROUND THE LIVING ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: This is cracking, love.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s great. Thank you Mrs. Bevan.

dialogues.speaker: JUDE
dialogues.text: This is my last warning. It’s Jude.

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: So I hear from my little girl that you've stolen her heart.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: Let me tell you, when you’re lucky enough to find an angel, hold on to her with everything you’ve got. These fucking lights! He gets up and storms to the back of the room, trying to the switch. BRYN starts to cry. Jordana and JUDE get up t comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Dad. Don’t...

dialogues.speaker: JUDE
dialogues.text: Bryn. Come on. Please. You're acting like I’m dead already. Come on. It’ll take more than some silly tumour to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: It might not.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Mum's going to be OK. And I've got Ol to look after me. OLIVER stares down into his plate  103 104 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 67.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 103
dialogues.text: EXT/INT. JORDANA’S HOUSE - EVENING 104 OLIVER in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JUDE
dialogues.text: So lovely to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It was great. Thank you. Really.

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: (shaking OLIVER'S hand and not letting go) Take care. I’d just like to thank you for being such a support to Jordana. We’ve been to hell and back. Thank you for walking through the fire with her. You’re a good lad. You’re part of the family now. Deal?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: Deal?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Sure. Deal.

dialogues.speaker: BRYN
dialogues.text: There we fucking go. Jordana comes out.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I‘1l walk to the bus stop with you.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk together in silence for a while. What? Pause

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Maybe you could come to the Hospital this Friday? Mum’1l have had her operation then and we could visit... If you felt like it...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Ah. Friday - I’ve got to do some Christmas shopping...

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA OLIVER
dialogues.text: - I just always leave it too late and I'd like to get you something good -

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: My mother might die.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Do you care about that or couldn’t you give a fuck?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I do. Clearly. I’1l come. When is it?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Friday.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Great. Actually that’s good. I can make that. Friday. Excellent. Your skin’s looking good. I definitely think you were allergic to your dog.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 69.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I’m eating better - following Mam’s special diet.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Because of the...

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: We eat lots of ginger now.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Friday?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANNA
dialogues.text: Visiting hours are 6 till 8.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Six till eight. Got it. Meet you there.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m like this. I don’t know. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's fine. Don’t feel you have to wait. It’s cold.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I bought you some matches. Swan extra long. JORDANA takes the box, removes a match, lights it and holds it up in front of her face.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I’ve noticed that when you light a match, the flame is the same shape as a falling tear.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew then it was too late to save her. She’d gone gooey in the middle. From now on she’ll buy little gifts for her favourite teachers and she'll admire the scenery and she’1ll buy soup for homeless people and she’1ll never burn my leg hair again.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Maybe I will go. It is pretty cold.  105 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 70. She gives him a long hug, Oliver tries to kiss her. She offers her cheek. She smiles and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JILL and LLOYD are watching GRAHAM’S INSTRUCTIONAL VIDEO. Graham’s video consists of -- Talking head against black -- Top lit Karate against black -- Staring to camera against black -- Reclining on a candle-surrounded bed ots beautiful gir against black. -- Running over the crest of a hill -- Romantic walk by a park OLIVER eavesdrops. NOTE there’s one version where they si in silence for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well, it is interesting... He’s really opening up his third eye there.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: It's just a metaphor, Lloyd. Don’t be so literal.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. I like the whole colour coding thing.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Well I'd like to go again and I'd like you to come

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You want us to go?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Yes. I do. We see more footage of Graham, sweeping at an opponent’s legs.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Do I have to bring shorts?  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 70A.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: It’s on Friday

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 71.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: So will you come?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I am intrigued...

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: This Friday.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: This Friday.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Don’t let me down. She gets ups and jumps as she sees OLIVER.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What ARE you doing? Lloyd and OLIVER exchange a look. We see more graham footage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER lies down on his bed, looking at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Friday. This friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER wanders through a hospital. He is holding a bunch red flowers. We adopt his POV as he tries to find JORDANA disorienting maze of corridors..

dialogues.speaker: FRAME, OR CLOCKWORK ORANGE SIDEWAYS TRACK TO HIM.
dialogues.text: JORDANA sits on a chair outside a ward, her eyes red from crying.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Jordana... She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?  107 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 72. She shakes her head again and starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me... OLIVER puts his hand on her shoulder in a gesture of support, but she shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: You should go in. Uncertainly, Oliver walks into the ward it turns into a B forest. The bed is in the middle of the forest. OLIVER APPROACHES. He sees a figure, covered by a sheet. He slowly approaches.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bevan? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bevan? It’s Oliver. Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I came round to dinner... He pulls back the sheet and sees himself, lying on the be Oliver on the bed’s eyes snap open. He grabs Oliver’s han and says, in Jude’s voice

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will never escape me. The thorns of the rose dig into OLIVER’S hand and blood drips onto the white sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver WAKES up and looks at his alarm clock. It is Friday. 5:00 am.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Not much need to interpret that one.

dialogues.speaker: 107B
dialogues.text: 108 109 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is now fully dressed. He looks exhausted. He stare at the alarm clock. It is now 17:55. He musters up his strength and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver walks and sees his Dad still in his room. INT. BEDROOM - SIX O’CLOCK. 108 OLIVER half enters. LLOYD is in his dressing gown, drinking hot lemon. They conduct the conversation via a mirror in the corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Dad, aren’t you going to Graham's thing?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Mm?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Graham's thing? It’s friday.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I thought you were going out.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yup. I’m meant to be at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well you'd better get along.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yup. Well. I probably should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver stands outside, with the front door open. He calls out.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Bye! Let me know how it goes! Lloyd wanders down the stairs, hot lemon in hand, and heads to the kitchen for a refill. OLIVER closes the fron door loudly. He then creeps round to the back of the house, making sure that Lloyd can’t see him. He watches his father, who’s still in the kitchen. Lloyd stands up and starts to rub his knuckles against his lips. He looks around the room. OLIVER provides what he imagines to be LLOYD’s internal monologue.  110 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 74.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at all this bullshit. What is any of it for? I need to save my marriage. I’m going to do it. I’m going to do that right now. I’m going to show Graham. I’m going to make that mystic bastard sorry he was ever born. We see LLOYD sit back down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just going to have a little sit down. But then, action! A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Action! And again.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Action! Oliver waits for a while, before walking back in.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Who would you save first in a house fire given the hypothetical situation that both mum and I were equally difficult to save?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (blankly, without hesitation) I would save your mother first so that we could have a better chance of working together to save you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Would you like me to stay with you?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. I’m good thanks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I think I should stay with you.  111 112 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 75.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1ll stay. I ought to stay. This is where I should be. I’1l top up your hot lemon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA is sitting in the reception. She wanders out of the front door. It swooshes shut behind her. She looks around and forlornly wanders back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER and LLOYD are having a lonely meal of soup.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Do you often feel like this?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Like what? Tired?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Down in the dumps.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Quite often.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: How long for?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Since I was about your age.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What does it feel like?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Like being underwater.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Is that why you became a marine biologist?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Have you always liked fish?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I suppose. I sort of drifted into it. No pun intended.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Does mum mind?  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 76.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I think she’d rather I earned more money...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No. You being underwater.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m sure she’d rather I wasn’t. It’s not that pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: The ocean’s six miles deep, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well remembered. They eat in silence for a bit. We hear the phone ring.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Could be mum...

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Or Jordana. They let the PHONE ring out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JORDANA is at a phone in the corridor. She replaces the receiver and wanders back down to see her mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JILL sits next to an empty seat. GRAHAM is holding forth to the assembled group.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: We will encounter people in our lives who will try to block our journey. I call these people colour blockers. They don’t want to see the full spectrum. They don’t want the white light.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LEISURE CENTRE-CARPARK OR LECTURE HALL,EMPTY EVE
dialogues.text: GRAHAM is holding JILL, who’s convulsed with sobs.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I think I’m just tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 117 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 77.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: There, there. It’s okay. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JILL drives back, quick and angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JILL returns home. She slams the door. And walks up the stairs. OLIVER and LLOYD watch her from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER lying on his bed, staring up at the ceiling ina very similar pose to one Lloyd might adopt. The phone rings. Without looking, he reaches over and picks up the phone from the floor of his room and puts it to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What is it? He listens for some time.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. I’m afraid now is not the time for that. I appreciate this must be frustrating. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jordana. Listen, I understand where you’re coming from but I’m not ready to break up with you yet. A further pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No you're not breaking up with me. You’re just having a nonage. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It means a period of immaturity. It was one of the words I highlighted in the dictionary I gave you. I have to go now. I’1l see you shortly. He calmly puts down the receiver.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 77A. 118 INT. OLIVER'S HOUSE. THE LIVING ROOM —- DAY 118 A WE TRACK in to the TV. The American soap is playing. A  119 120

dialogues.speaker: 120A
dialogues.text: 121 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 78.

dialogues.speaker: TV KID
dialogues.text: This is the best Christmas ever.

dialogues.speaker: TV DAD
dialogues.text: I’ve got one other thing that you might like. Close your eyes. He brings out a woman from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: TV KID
dialogues.text: Mom? You're alive! We pan onto the TATES opening presents in their living room. Jill gets a kettle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent Christmas dinner; Jill declines a cracker.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Christmas was a mixed affair. Negatives include Jordana trying to dump me and my mum not speaking to my Dad. On the plus side, I had plenty of time to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Jill watch TV at opposite ends of the sofa We see OLIVER reading a book called. RELATIONSHIPS: MAKIN THEM WORK. JILL gets ups and passes OLIVER.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Tell your father I’m going for a drive.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Dad says okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd is putting up a banner saying, ‘HAPPY NEW YEAR’. He places some nibbles on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER at his typewriter.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 78A.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In an effort to reconcile them, I’ve written a letter to my mum from my father. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 79.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I filled it with romance and promise. It’s New Year's Eve. A time for fresh beginnings. I cannot fail. 122pt1 INT. OLIVER'S HOUSE - HIS PARENT’S BEDROOM/HALL OU We see OLIVER slip the envelope under the door. We see a zoom into the letter. Time cut. 122 pt2 JILL reading the letter. 122 pt2

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Dear Jill, it’s been too long since we’ve had the dimmer switch down half-way. Let me re-discover your sweet spot. Best wishes from your husband, Lloyd. Happy New Year in advance.” 122 pt3 INT. OLIVER'S BEDROOM - DAY 122 pt3

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oliver! Oliver is on his bed. He is reading a book called ‘Making Relationships Work’.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sharper) Oliver! 122 pt2 INT. OLIVER’S HOUSE. HIS PARENT’S BEDROOM - LATER

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 79A.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It looks like a letter but I don’t know what’s in it.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I think you do know.  123

dialogues.speaker: 123A
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 80.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why did you write this, Oliver? JILL grabs OLIVER and shakes him slightly.

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This isn’t funny, Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: OK. If I did write it, and I’m not as yet admitting that I did, it'd only be because I spoke to Dad and this is what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You spoke to Dad?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: He knows he’s been imperfect.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oliver, what did you talk about?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Listen... He takes a step forward, almost as if he’s in a soap opera, and places a hand on JILL’S shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He still finds you attractive. He still wants to make love to you.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oliver, are you making this up?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Dad and I have discussed this and we both want to make this marriage work. OLIVER tries to hold her gaze with a look of absolute sincerity. JILL seems lost for words.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Go to your room, please.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OLIVER'S BEDROOM- LATER
dialogues.text: OLIVER paces for a while and then sits down and starts to write. We see the following appear on the typewriter: ‘Dear Jill, I understand that you've recently received a1 letter from Oliver. I think the key thing is to forgive ' Oliver stops - he hears the sound of his parents’ car. He runs downstairs.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 80A. 123xX EXT. HOUSE - EVENING 123X * He sees his mum driving off, down the bottom of the road.  124

dialogues.speaker: 124A
dialogues.text: 125 126 127 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER runs back into the hall. He sees a note by the phone. He picks it up. INSERT NOTE: ‘GOING TO THE BEACH WITH GRAHAM. I WILL NOT BE BACK TONIGHT.’ He looks back at LLOYD. He looks at LLoyd, sitting in his armchair under the ‘happy new year’ banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER parks his bike and wanders towards the beach. He sees GRAHAM’S VAN in the CARPARK.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On New Year’s Eve, everyone from the town goes to the beach. Chips says that if a girl won’t get off with you on New Year’s Eve, you may as well cut it off. I’m beginning to think he and I may grow apart when we get older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fireworks and sparklers illuminate the sky. OLIVER walks through the crowd, looking for GRAHAM and his MOTHER, but is overwhelmed by the throng. Lots of people seem to be kissing. Oliver looks fevered. He stops short, as he sees Jordana who is giggling next t boy with a very long neck. She is unaware of his presence Then, before he is diverted, he sees Graham and Jill wand past. They’re being very tactile. He looks back at Jordan but, though it pains him, he is compelled to follow Jill.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 81A. OLIVER presses on. Fireworks explode around him. It’s difficult, and he sees JILL and GRAHAM make pace back to the van.  128 129 130 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees JILL and GRAHAM GIGGLING and FLIRTING. They are kissing. GRAHAM unlocks the back of his van and he and JILL crawl in. JILL’S CAR IS ALSO THERE. He walks up to the van and tries to see in. He can hear laughing and make out sounds. He staggers back and throws an empty bottle of 20/20 at the van. He panics and hides under a nearby car. GRAHAM jumps out, wearing a kimono. Oliver is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Fuck off! We see inside the van. JILL looks in the mirror. We see a realisation. What am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER cycling, crying. The dull sound of fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Fucking mystic. Motherfucking mystic. He takes out the kitchen roll of anti-depressants and swallows a couple

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s start her up again. He tries to start up again.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I ought to get back?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Ought you?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Okay. I’1l drive you. Just give me a minute. I’m not really safe to drive like this. He looks down. He has an erection.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh, for God’s sake.  131 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 82A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER arrives back at his house. Unsteadily he puts the key in the door. He sees LLOYD is sitting on top of the sofa in his dressing gown. 131  132 133 134 135 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 83. The dull thud of fireworks is heard off-screen. He sips his lemon drink. He’s watching a video tape of himself on open university.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: It is indeed hard to measure exactly how fast fish are. The most reliable method is to race water against the fish in a water column and see at what speed the fish stops trying to fight the flow. Is this as fast as it can go? We can’t say. Maybe it just reaches a point where it gives up... CLOSE ON OLIVER, we can hear the dull thud of fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER rifles through the draws in the kitchen. He finds some matches and a torch light. He puts on a pair red gardening gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets a hammer out of a tool box and tucks it into his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver looks at his reflection in a puddle. He takes some mud from the floor and smears it on his face. He’s wearin a burglar’s hat. He spits into the puddle and watches his reflection ripple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the smash of glass. OLIVER breaks in and starts looking around with only the flashlight to guide him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure what my plan was when I broke into Graham's house. I just wanted to leave the impression that I was deranged and therefore capable of anything. He takes a teaspoon and puts it into Graham’s microwave. He sees a box of GRAHAM’S VIDEOS. He unspools the tape inside them.  136 137 138 139 140 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 84. He finds a DRINKS cupboard. He pours himself a large measure of BRANDY into a large brandy glass. He sees VARIOUS BITS OF HEATSEEKERS MEMORABLIA - AN ANNUAL, A TOY, a woven rug with Graham’s face on it AND THE TITLE ‘HEATSEEKERS’. He pisses on GRAHAM’S WOOLLEN FACE while sipping his drink. UNSTEADILY, he walks upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM'S VAN passes along a road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER opens a drawer in a cabinet and rifles through. He sees a number of drawings/plans for GRAHAM’S VAN and a number of charcoal drawings of women. KIM-LIN, his MUM, a few others. Some quite good line drawings, some more colourful fantasy scenarios that have the feel of the drawing on his van. There is a portrait of Graham and Jil together, both on a flying unicorn, surrounded by white light and stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE shots of GRAHAM and JILL. They stare ahead. Underli - looking frightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees a heart shaped water bottle on the bed. OLIVER lights a match and tosses it on the bed. He throws on some brandy, but it manages to put out the fire. He lights another match and tries to set light to a pillow. It flames up. He panics and snatches the water bottle fro the covers and empties it out on the fire. He shakes the duvet to put out the fire. The smoke gets in his eyes and he starts to feel sick. He vomits in the corner of the room. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE OLIVER’S HOUSE - NIGHT 140 GRAHAM'S VAN pulls up. JILL gets out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I don’t regret what’s happened tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Well, I do.  141 142 143 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 85. She walks unsteadily into her house. GRAHAM watches her. He then gets out and walks to his front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER is lying down on the bed, half-unconscious

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? OLIVER hides under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM ascends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Kim-Lin? Is that you? Do you still have a key? That’s naughty. He enters the bedroom and switches on the light. He sees person-shaped mound under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kim-Lin, what’s going on? He pulls back the bedsheet.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: My name is not Kim-Lin. My name is Oliver Tate. OLIVER blacks out. WE FADE DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 143
dialogues.text: 144 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAHAM gently places OLIVER on the TATE threshold.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You're going to be okay, little guy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Don’t ever come back. Graham accepts this. He rings the bell and then trots back down the drive. Lloyd comes out and looks around, not seeing Oliver on th steps.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hello? GRAHAM shouts from a distance and indicates to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Your son...!

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What’s he done?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: He broke into my house. It’s fine!

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Right - thanks. Sorry! Do you want to come in for a coffee?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No thanks - I get palpitations/I get anxious!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (from the floor, half to himself) Don’t you ever come back you fucking mystic.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oliver. This is not acceptable. We see JILL appear at the window. We see Graham’s POV of JILL. He looks away.  145 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 87. (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LLoyd and Jill eneter. There is a bucket next to the bed. OLIVER lies under the covers, sore from sickness. His parents are sat on the edge of the bed. LLOYD ruffles his hair.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Knock. Knock.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Just go in.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I saw mum with Graham at the beach.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Your Mum’s told me everything-

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Did she say she went into his van? The one with his face on it?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Did she say what happened in the van with his face on it?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Aren’t you angry?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Worse things have happened at sea.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What did happen?  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 89.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That’s between your mother and I.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Lloyd. I think we should be honest. Sweet pea: I gave Graham a hand job. Do you want to ask anything about that? Do you want to add anything Lloyd? I was drunk and I thought it - I was trying to relax Graham. It was a silly thing to do. Your father and I have discussed it. And that’s the last we'll say if that’s OK with everyone. Is there anything you'd like to talk about? OLIVER tries to lean over the bed vomit, but he’s too slow to reach the bucket. He leaves a string of bubbly saliva on his pillow.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Jordana and I are having relationship problems. It’s difficult... I suppose it won’t matter when I’m thirty-eight... but I’m upset about it... (to LLOYD) You should be more angry with her.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Why would I be angry with Jordana? Oh you mean me. Yes. I am. I’m upset. Go to sleep now, Ol. We’re not going to punish you now, but your mother and I are going to talk about what you’ve done.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Maybe you should talk about what you've done.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Don’t push it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: We'll talk about that too. You should go back to sleep.  146 147 148 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 90. INT. OLIVER'S PARENTS’ BEDROOM - EARLY MORNING 146 JILL and LLOYD, unsteady from drink, change for bed.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You should be more angry.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m very angry. I am very angry.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You know what I did.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I know. I’ve taken it on board.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I wanted to do it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m very upset.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Do you hate me now?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m hiding it.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You're sweet.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Your hair was better when it was longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER picks up a padded envelope addressed to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens it. JORDANA’S CLIPPER, some matches, the books OLIVER bought her and a letter fall out. NOTE we film JORDANA reading this out. We do this against black in the studio.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Oliver, I tried to tell you but I figure you'll probably only believe me if it’s in writing. It’s over. I enclose my Clipper as a parting gift for you. Also, I think you should know I’ve found someone else. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 90A.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When we are in school together, try not to look upset. I know you are a good actor. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 149 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 91.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: PS you were right about my being allergic to dogs. I got tested. Oh, and in case you’re interested, my mum’s fine now. Sorry if it made you feel awkward. OLIVER goes over to the stereo and puts LLOYD’S break up mix on. He lies on the bed trying to light the CLIPPER in a cool way. He looks at the shape of the fire. He uses it to light a match. WE see the bed slowly float out to sea. (BLUE SCREEN) Then, over music:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER is on the PHONE. He is trying to get through to JORDANA.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Could you tell her I called? OLIVER does a variation on this in the hallway, museum, A a phone box B

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: None of this will matter when I’m thirty-eight, but it’s been two months since Jordana last spoke to me. I’ve tried several times to call, but to no avail.  150

dialogues.speaker: 150G
dialogues.text: 151 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 91A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER walks across the playground OLIVER WALKS down a long corridor, filled with kids shout and screaming. We track along with JORDANA and her new boyfriend (16) wh has a very long NECK. We reveal OLIVER, secretly watching them. They see him, OLIVER tries to casually walk away. OLIVER stares at a bowl of steaming yellow custard in the refectory. He gets up and walks to the window. He stares at... CHIPS, JORDANA, KEIRON and the new boyfriend plus a coupl of others, messing about together. Same place he saw ZOE being teased.

dialogues.speaker: DISSECTING A RAT. OLIVER LOOKS AT HIS, DEJECTED.
dialogues.text: Driving along with LLOYD and JILL. OLIVER now has no desi to change the gears.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her new boyfriend’s has an incredibly long neck. Just thinking about giraffes makes me angry. Chips said that the break up has made things awkward for him. He didn’t want to chose between us, but Jordana knows more girls so he thought it best to keep in with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. DAVEY is conducting a lesson - some impro. OLIVER wal up a corridor and knocks on the door, letter in hand. Mr. DAVEY comes to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wish I could hand in this excuse note. JILL V.O. Please may Oliver be excused from class. His tiny heart is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 152 153 154 155 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 91B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER stares at his reflection in the water. He throws i about two dozen condoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER is with his DAD, labelling jars.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After school I have to go to my Dad’s work and help him categorise fish. He says I have to keep doing this until I’ve paid off the damage to Graham's house. There are more types of fish than you'd ever believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Jill are finishing off dinner. OLIVER enters, fills up a flask with hot lemon and walks back out.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then after dinner, I make a pilgrimage to the places Jordana and I used to kiss and frig each other off. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 155AC
dialogues.text: SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 93.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In each location I lay a single red rose. When I’m depressed I tend towards symbolism. I’ve already turned these moments into the super 8 footage of memory. We see Oliver lay the first rose in a certain place. We A cut to all these places - empty, devoid of people. There is a single red rose in each one. We film these normally and on super 8. During the last two weeks of shooting we take super 8 of scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER on his own. He watches a rose float in the swimmin pool. He then gets up and calmly jumps into the pool, ful clothed. We follow him under water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bath, he re-emerges and blinks. He lies back under water and opens his eyes and stares straight at us. Sudde he feels a hand on his chest. He starts thrashing about, unable to move. He looks up and sees himself, mug of hot lemon in hand, pushing down. The murdering OLIVER calmly takes a swig of drink. INT. OLIVER’S BEDROOM- EVENING 155AC OLIVER sits up in bed and switches on the light. Leans against the wall. On it are the dozens and dozens of Polaroids of JORDANA and OLIVER kissing.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In my other recurring dream I mentally rehearse the end scene. The one where it’s getting dark and I mistake a girl for Jordana We see a POV SHOT walking up to a girl facing away from B OLIVER. She turns round to camera, but it’s not JORDANA.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - a girl with the exact same frame and the exact same hair - and when she turns around I see that her face is nothing like Jordana’s and she asks if she knows me and I look traumatized and say, ‘No, I’m sorry, no, you don’t know me, nobody knows me.’  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 92A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAFYDD, CHIPS, KEIRON, JORDANA and two other GIRLS are burning a Christmas tree on an industrial estate. Oliver watches through the fence.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will remain a victim forever, like Zoe, who is probably, right at this moment, wallowing in her own sorrowful existence, unable to move her massive bulk as bunions grow in the folds of her voluminous skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boring lesson w/Mr. Davey, we slowly zoom into Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: 158A
dialogues.text: 159 160 161 162 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver looking at a copy of the local news. We see an article on Zoe. There’s a post-it note on it from Jill. ‘Isn't this your friend Zoe?! Mum x’ ‘Local girl Zoe Preece wins modelling contract’. There is a quote: “the kids at school called me fat. I suppose they should see m now.” “I was so unhappy the weight just fell off.” There is a photo-shopped picture of Zoe, looking much thinner. OLIVER has a bottle of whiskey next to him. He takes a gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER ripping up some books and letting the pages flutte into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JILL, LLOYD, OLIVER see GRAHAM taking things into his van There is a FOR SALE SIGN UP outside his house.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 161
dialogues.text: INT. PARENTS’ BEDRROM - EVENING 162 OLIVER walks in with his hot lemon. The dimmer switch is half-way. His parents are kissing and cuddling.  163 164 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 95.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I think this will matter when I’m thirty-eight. They scramble and pull the covers around themselves.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Don’t you knock anymore?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What was that O1?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: With Jordana. It will matter when I’m thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Go to sleep, Ol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. DAVEY is DRONING on. Oliver is staring into space. He then looks down at a piece of paper. INSERT: The camera focuses on a piece of A4. We see: A ‘REASONS FOR NOT KILLING MYSELF: 1. MESS/CLEAN UP ISSUES 2. MAKES PARENTS LOOK BAD. He writes ‘3. WOULD NEVER SEE JORDANA BEVAN AGAIN.’ CHIPS looks over, sees it, then swipes it. OLIVER then tries to get it back. MR. DAVEY sees the ensuing struggle.

dialogues.speaker: MR DAVEY
dialogues.text: What’s so interesting?

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: Ask Tate.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Nothing, sir.  165 166 167 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 96.

dialogues.speaker: MR DAVEY
dialogues.text: There’s obviously something on that piece of paper that’s deeply fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: There honestly isn’t sir.

dialogues.speaker: MR DAVEY
dialogues.text: You know the rules. Up you come. OLIVER makes a slow death row walk up to the front. The class woofs and hollers. He holds up the paper and looks at the grinning melee in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Reasons for not killing myself. 1. Mess/clean up issues 2. Makes Parents look bad 3. Would never see Jordana again. And ‘3’ is circled. The class howls. ANGLE on JORDANA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR.DAVEY has kept OLIVER behind.

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVEY
dialogues.text: You're sure you were joking...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course...

dialogues.speaker: MR. DAVEY
dialogues.text: Because if you ever have those thoughts, you must feel... OLIVER looks out of the window at the ape like faces of his classmates. Mr. Davey’s voice fades out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver has to walk along a corridor of howling kids. He glances as JORDANA as he rushes to his next class, head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER is getting ribbed by everyone.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: Oh, Jordana save me...!  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 97.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Chips. He launches at him and knocks him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS
dialogues.text: What the fuck’s wrong with you? OLIVER walks off.

dialogues.speaker: CHIPS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me know if you need a hand killing yourself. I’m sure your parents would understand. JORDANA watches. She and OLIVER share a look. She is standing next to her boyfriend. OLIVER walks up to her.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I didn’t come to the hospital. I thought my parents were going to split up and I didn’t want to look weak or for things to change. My mum gave a handjob to a mystic and also I was worried about the charter. Our charter, and rule 3 in particular, but I was wrong. I think I was maybe frightened. I made a mistake. It was wrong. I’m full of regret. This is the moment where you leave him and come with me.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Is it?  168 169 170 SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 98.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes. Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: No... OLIVER nods, then runs off like a small boy. He runs across the school playing fields He runs down a street outside He runs down to the beach, up the wall looking out and st there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER stands, looking out. He has been crying. His eye i caught by a figure, quite a way off engaged in a tug of war with a large GREYHOUND, carrying a plastic bag of dog poo. He walks towards the figure, and, as it becomes more distinct he half-runs. He gets closer. The figure turns round. It’s JORDANA.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It is you... I thought it might not be but it is. I thought this’d be like the bit in the film where the protagonist - Why have you got a dog? I thought you were allergic to dogs.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANNA
dialogues.text: Oliver -

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Where’s your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: He’s not my boyfriend maybe. She tries to light her cigarette. It’s windy and the matches keep blowing out. OLIVER takes out her RED LIGHTE and helps. They huddle together trying to block out the wind. They’re closer than JORDANA would like. He looks at her hands as she tries to cup the round the lighter.  She throws SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 99.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Your skin’s looking bad. (beat) Your skin’s looking terrible. It’s probably the dog.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I don’t care about my fucking skin.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Why on earth did you get a new dog?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANNA
dialogues.text: Because I like dogs. Okay? the bag of dog poo at him.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: Why are you such a total dick?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. I was crying earlier. Look. My eyes are probably red.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: They look normal.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh. Maybe my eyes don’t go red when I cry.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: You could have told me about your parents.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I know. I should’ve.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: You’re not the only person in the world.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Do you think we can work things out?

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I don’t really like you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don't really like me either. But I think I have certain qualities. They look at one another. She smiles.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 98A.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We used to come here didn’t we? Ask me how deep the ocean is.  SUBMARINE 23rd NOVEMBER 2009 RED 100.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: How deep is the ocean?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I know the answer.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: How deep is it?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m not going to say.

dialogues.speaker: JORDANA
dialogues.text: I’m broken hearted

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: The ocean is six miles deep. The tide comes in and wets their feet. They both stay there. THE END.
